subject: Gardening
title: Seeds That Wait Decades
description: A quick, practical guide to Seeds That Wait Decades.

hook.text: A 2,000-year-old date palm seed found at Masada was planted in 2005. It germinated. Scientists named it Methuselah.

buildup.text: Seeds can enter dormancyâ€”a suspended stateâ€”waiting for the right conditions to germinate, sometimes for centuries.

discovery.text: Dormancy mechanisms include hard coats, chemical inhibitors, and temperature requirements that filter false starts.

twist.text: Fire-adapted plants like lodgepole pine seal their cones with resin. Only wildfire heat melts it, releasing seeds.

climax.text: Seed dormancy is a time capsule strategy. Plants bet on the future by storing life in suspended animation.

punchline.text: A seed is a plant's bet on a better tomorrow.

quiz.question: How do lodgepole pine trees ensure their seeds germinate after a wildfire?
options: Seeds are coated in fire-resistant gel that activates with ash
Cones are sealed with resin that only melts in the heat of a wildfire
Seeds are buried deep underground where fire can't reach them
